metadata.case_name: Workmen of Subong Tea Estate v. M/s Macneill Barry Ltd. & M/s Gungaram Tarachand

facts.text: Agreement of transfer between respondent No. 1 (Vendor, M/s Macneill Barry Ltd.) and respondent No. 2 (Vendee, M/s Gungaram Tarachand) reached on 12th January 1959, to take effect from 1st January 1959, subject to Reserve Bank of India approval.
Reserve Bank of India approval accorded on 15th July 1959; conveyance executed on 28th December 1959.
Pending execution of conveyance, Vendee put in possession of tea garden on 17th February 1959.

On 31st August 1959, Mr. Hammond (Manager of Vendor) served notices on 8 employees terminating services from 1st October 1959, paid retrenchment compensation under s.25F and pro rata leave wages on 31st August 1959.
On 1st September 1959, Union protested retrenchment, claiming Vendor had no authority post 17th February 1959.
Dispute referred by Governor of Assam under s.10(1)(d) of Industrial Disputes Act to Industrial Tribunal Assam (Reference No. 39/59), award dated 5th July 1961.

Four issues referred: (1) Whether retrenchment justified? (2) Whether respondent No.2 justified in refusing continuity of service? (3) Entitlement to reinstatement? (4) Further relief if retrenchment valid.
Letter dated 24/26 December 1958 from Vendor's Managing Agents: agreed to deliver possession pending sale completion, management and operational control to Vendee post-possession.
Vendee accepted terms in paras 10 and 13 of Vendor's letter on 5th January 1959.
On 9th February 1959, Vendor proposed lay-off for economy, sought Vendee's advice; Vendee opposed, no lay-off in Subong Tea Estate.
Possession handed over by Mr. Hammond to Vendee's Manager on 17th February 1959.
Vendee paid leave pay and wages to employees post-possession; controlled, directed and supervised work.
On 25th August 1959, Vendee instructed Vendor to terminate surplus staff from 1st September 1959.

Sale deed executed 28th December 1959 for Rs. 3,75,000, deemed effective from 1st January 1959; Vendee covenanted to continue services or pay compensation per law (except European management/executive staff).
Union enquired about transfer on 13th January 1959 and 17th April 1959, citing s.25FF.
Tribunal held retrenchment valid by Vendor, paid compensation; recommended ex-gratia gratuity for two employees.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned retrenchment of the 8 workmen was justified
Whether respondent No. 2 justified in refusing continuity of service and original terms and conditions
Whether workmen entitled to reinstatement and other relief
Whether retrenched workmen entitled to further relief if retrenchment valid
Applicability of s.25FF to the transfer and whether retrenchment valid under s.25F and s.25G

petitioner_arguments.text: At relevant date of retrenchment, respondent No. 2 was employer post-transfer on 17th February 1959; respondent No. 1 had no authority; retrenchment invalid, not justified under s.25F, not per s.25G principles.
Retrenchment after transfer of management; workmen continued under Vendee, so s.25FF not applicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Vendor (respondent 1) was employer at retrenchment date; Vendee managed as agent; retrenchment per terms of transfer, attracts s.25FF; compensation paid adequate.
Delivery of possession on 17th Feb not transfer of management under s.25FF; subject to RBI approval and retrenchment of surplus staff as condition precedent.

court_reasoning.text: Post RBI approval on 15 July 1959, Vendee became owner; conduct showed Vendee as employer (paid wages, controlled work, decided lay-off, purchases).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vendee took charge and became employer of employees including 8 retrenched.

court_reasoning.text: Retrenchment not consequent on transfer but after; by Vendee who became employer; s.25FF inapplicable.
Notices by Hammond and payment explained as complying with s.25FF ostensibly; acceptance of compensation under duress, no bar in industrial adjudication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrenchment invalid as Vendor ceased to be employer.

court_reasoning.text: No compliance with s.25F or s.25G by Vendee; no reasons recorded for s.25G departure; no case made for surplus employees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrenchment invalid, terminates no employer-employee relation.

holdings.text: Retrenchment invalid; s.25FF inapplicable as effected by transferee (Vendee) after becoming employer.
Workmen entitled to reinstatement with continuity of service and back wages, adjust for retrenchment compensation paid.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions precedent and procedure for retrenchment (25F,25G); compensation on transfer of undertaking (25FF); re-employment preference (25H); reference for adjudication (10(1)(d))

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal award set aside; respondent No. 2 directed to reinstate 8 workmen with continuity of service and pay back wages from retrenchment date to reinstatement, adjusting retrenchment compensation paid.
outcome.relief_granted: Reinstatement with continuity of service and back wages (adjusted for compensation received)

key_quotes.text: the Vendee who had already obtained possession of the estate became the owner of the property and his possession became the possession of the owner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines transfer of ownership post-RBI approval

key_quotes.text: the conduct of the parties clearly shows that the Vendee was the employer and the workmen working in the garden including the 8 retrenched workmen were the Vendees employees.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the impugned retrenchment cannot, therefore, be taken to attract the operation of s. 25FF at all.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects applicability of s.25FF, basis for invalidity
